repnme.cdata!:
Thailand - Additional Financing for
            Highways Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Highways Management Project for
            Thailand had a moderately unsatisfactory outcome, with the
            performances of both the Bank and the borrower deemed
            moderately unsatisfactory as well. While most of the project
            development objective indicators and intermediate outcome
            indicators were achieved fully or at least partially, three
            were not achieved. The reasons for the moderately
            unsatisfactory outcome were primarily the fact that some
            targets were not achieved, and also because certain
            important social issues were not addressed specifically
            during project implementation. Significant lessons learned
            during the course of implementing the project were: 1) the
            Bank should assess the interest of the borrower for proposed
            activities carefully, and should not push its own agenda.
            The implementing agency also should assess its own interests
            and ownership of project activities seriously and convey
            them clearly; 2) usage of additional financing for
            "scale up" should be examined carefully; 3)
            performance indicators and targets should be clearly defined
            and the monitoring process should be agreed firmly at
            appraisal; 4) improving road safety needs continuous
            efforts; and 5) the fiduciary requirements for middle income
            clients need to be monitored carefully.

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Highways Management Project for Thailand is to enhance the
            efficiency, productive use, and management of the road
            network. Specifically, it supports the commercialization of
            the road sector, strengthens the operations of the
            Department of Highways, helps preserve road assets, and
            improves competition and transparency in the award of
            contracts. The project implementation progress for
            activities is near completion, the project is rated
            unsatisfactory due to slow procurement process for
            activities under the additional financing. All civil works
            have been completed with the remaining fund of US$441,283
            under this category. All periodic maintenance works were
            completed by September 2011 and the International
            Procurement Consultant (IPC) has been hired since March 9,
            2011. The only remaining activity is Consultancy for the
            Design of Performance-Based Contracts (PBC), estimated at US$350,000.

Thailand - Highways Management

14458926.theme: Public expenditure, financial management and procurement,Injuries and non-communicable diseases,Trade facilitation and market access,Micro, Small and Medium Enterprise support,Infrastructure services for private sector development
14458926.trustfund: TF090486-COMMUNITY YOUTH HELMET USE PROGRAM,TF090414-COMMUNITY YOUTH HELMET USE PROGRAM
14458926.majtheme: Public sector governance,Human development,Trade and integration,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
This project paper introduce the
            following changes to the Thailand Highways Management
            Project: (a) to reallocate the loan proceeds that remain
            uncommitted because of the cancellation of two consultancies
            to finance additional activities (mainly civil works) within
            the same scope of the project and to modify the project
            outputs accordingly; (b) to extend the loan closing date to
            June 30, 2010 (which would be the third extension of the
            closing date); (c) to address the slight discrepancies in
            the formulation of the project development objective (PDO)
            between the project appraisal document (PAD) and loan
            agreement; and (d) to make amendments to the loan agreement
            accordingly. The restructuring is mainly to address the
            project implementation problems caused by the failed
            procurement processes for the two consultancies and to make
            productive use of the uncommitted loan funds for achieving
            the project outcomes. An additional financing to the project
            is being prepared in parallel to this restructuring. The
            additional financing will mainly support the widening of
            five priority national highway stretches, totaling 216 km.
            Given the uncertain timing of the parliamentary approval of
            this additional financing, it has been decided to process
            the restructuring first as the Department of Highways (DOH)
            is ready to use the uncommitted loan proceeds for the
            much-needed periodic maintenance works, which are also
            expected to be helpful for the businesses of small- and
            medium-sized construction enterprises at the time of
            economic downturn.
